Comment: Many of the checks and balances were predicated on the assumption that the US would be a no-party system.  There was no Plan B if that didn't turn out to be true.  And of course, it wasn't true.  The founders inadvertently laid the groundwork for a two-party system.  That erodes the checks and balances provided by Congress as the representatives will usually back a president of their party.  Instead of jealously guarding their roles as legislators, they fall into line in their roles as party members.    With only two parties, there will be almost always be enough representatives in the president's party that they can impact the result.  This of course is worse when there is a trifecta, as we have right now.
